member.name: T:DiscUtils.AligningStream
member.summary: Aligns I/O to a given block size.
member.remarks: Uses the read-modify-write pattern to align I/O.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.WrappingMappedStream`1
member.summary: Base class for streams that wrap another stream.
member.typeparam: The type of stream to wrap.
member.remarks: Provides the default implementation of methods & properties, so wrapping streams need only override the methods they need to intercept.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.MappedStream
member.summary: Base class for streams that are essentially a mapping onto a parent stream.
member.remarks: This class provides access to the mapping underlying the stream, enabling callers to convert a byte range in this stream into one or more ranges in the parent stream.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.SparseStream
member.summary: Represents a sparse stream.
member.remarks: A sparse stream is a logically contiguous stream where some parts of the stream aren't stored. The unstored parts are implicitly zero-byte ranges.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Converts any stream into a sparse stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
member.remarks: The returned stream has the entire wrapped stream as a single extent.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DiscUtils.StreamExtent})
member.summary: Converts any stream into a sparse stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
The set of extents actually stored in stream
member.remarks: The returned stream has the entire wrapped stream as a single extent.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Pump(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Efficiently pumps data from a sparse stream to another stream.
member.param: The sparse stream to pump from.
The stream to pump to.
member.remarks: must support seeking.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Pump(System.IO.Stream,System.IO.Stream,System.Int32)
member.summary: Efficiently pumps data from a sparse stream to another stream.
member.param: The stream to pump from.
The stream to pump to.
The smallest sequence of zero bytes that will be skipped when writing to
member.remarks: must support seeking.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.ReadOnly(DiscUtils.SparseStream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Wraps a sparse stream in a read-only wrapper, preventing modification.
member.param: The stream to make read-only
Whether to transfer responsibility for calling Dispose on toWrap

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Clear(System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the stream.
member.param: The number of bytes (from the current position) to clear

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the stream, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a stream, regardless of the underlying stream implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.SparseStream.GetExtentsInRange(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Gets the parts of a stream that are stored, within a specified range.
member.param: The offset of the first byte of interest
The number of bytes of interest
member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes

member.name: P:DiscUtils.SparseStream.Extents
member.summary: Gets the parts of the stream that are stored.
member.remarks: This may be an empty enumeration if all bytes are zero.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream)

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.FromStream(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Ownership,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{DiscUtils.StreamExtent})
member.summary: Converts any stream into a non-linear stream.
member.param: The stream to convert.
true to have the new stream dispose the wrapped stream when it is disposed.
The set of extents actually stored in stream
member.remarks: The wrapped stream is assumed to be a linear stream (such that any byte range maps directly onto the parent stream)

member.name: M:DiscUtils.MappedStream.MapContent(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Maps a logical range down to storage locations.
member.param: The first logical range to map
The length of the range to map
member.returns: One or more stream extents specifying the storage locations that correspond to the identified logical extent range.

remarks.para: As far as possible, the stream extents are returned in logical disk order - however, due to the nature of non-linear streams, not all of the range may actually be stored, or some or all of the range may be compressed - thus reading the returned stream extents is not equivalent to reading the logical disk range.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.PartitionTable.Create(DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new partition that encompasses the entire disk.
member.param: The partition type
Whether the partition is active (bootable)
member.remarks: The partition table must be empty before this method is called, otherwise IOException is thrown.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.PartitionTable.Create(System.Int64,DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new partition with a target size.
member.param: The target size (in bytes)
The partition type
Whether the partition is active (bootable)
member.returns: The index of the new partition

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.PartitionTable.CreateAligned(DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new aligned partition that encompasses the entire disk.
member.param: The partition type
Whether the partition is active (bootable)
The alignment (in byte)
member.remarks: The partition table must be empty before this method is called, otherwise IOException is thrown.

Traditionally partitions were aligned to the physical structure of the underlying disk, however with modern storage greater efficiency is acheived by aligning partitions on large values that are a power of two.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.PartitionTable.CreateAligned(System.Int64,DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean,System.Int32)

The alignment (in byte)
member.returns: The index of the new partition
member.remarks: Traditionally partitions were aligned to the physical structure of the underlying disk, however with modern storage greater efficiency is acheived by aligning partitions on large values that are a power of two.

member.summary: Gets or sets the size (in bytes) of each cached block.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.ReadCacheSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size (in bytes) of the read cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.LargeReadSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum read size that will be cached.
member.remarks: Large reads are not cached, on the assumption they will not be repeated. This setting controls what is considered 'large'. Any read that is more than this many bytes will not be cached.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheSettings.OptimumReadSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the optimum size of a read to the wrapped stream.
member.remarks: This value must be a multiple of BlockSize

member.name: T:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics
member.summary: Statistical information about the effectiveness of a BlockCache instance.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.LargeReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested 'large' reads, as defined by the LargeReadSize setting.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.UnalignedReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested unaligned reads.
member.remarks: Unaligned reads are reads where the read doesn't start on a multiple of the block size.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalReadsIn
member.summary: Gets the total number of requested reads.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalReadsOut
member.summary: Gets the total number of reads passed on by the cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.ReadCacheHits
member.summary: Gets the number of times a read request was serviced (in part or whole) from the cache.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.ReadCacheMisses
member.summary: Gets the number of time a read request was serviced (in part or whole) from the wrapped stream.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.UnalignedWritesIn
member.summary: Gets the number of requested unaligned writes.
member.remarks: Unaligned writes are writes where the write doesn't start on a multiple of the block size.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.TotalWritesIn
member.summary: Gets the total number of requested writes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.BlockCacheStatistics.FreeReadBlocks
member.summary: Gets the number of free blocks in the read cache.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Buffer
member.summary: Abstract base class for implementations of IBuffer.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.IBuffer
member.summary: Interface shared by all buffers.
member.remarks: Buffers are very similar to streams, except the buffer has no notion of 'current position'. All I/O operations instead specify the position, as needed. Buffers also support sparse behaviour.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Read(System.Int64,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads from the buffer into a byte array.
member.param: The offset within the buffer to start reading.
The destination byte array.
The start offset within the destination buffer.
The number of bytes to read.
member.returns: The actual number of bytes read

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Write(System.Int64,System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes a byte array into the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The source byte array.
The start offset within the source byte array.
The number of bytes to write.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Clear(System.Int64,System.Int32)
member.summary: Clears bytes from the buffer.
member.param: The start offset within the buffer.
The number of bytes to clear

remarks.para: Logically equivalent to writing count null/zero bytes to the buffer, some implementations determine that some (or all) of the range indicated is not actually stored. There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a buffer, regardless of the underlying buffer implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Flush
member.summary: Flushes all data to the underlying storage.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.SetCapacity(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the capacity of the buffer, truncating if appropriate.
member.param: The desired capacity of the buffer.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.IBuffer.GetExtentsInRange(System.Int64,System.Int64)
member.summary: Gets the parts of a buffer that are stored, within a specified range.
member.param: The offset of the first byte of interest
The number of bytes of interest
member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes

member.name: P:DiscUtils.IBuffer.CanRead
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this buffer can be read.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether this buffer can be modified.

member.summary: Gets the current capacity of the buffer, in bytes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.IBuffer.Extents
member.summary: Gets the parts of the buffer that are stored.
member.remarks: This may be an empty enumeration if all bytes are zero.

There is no direct, automatic, correspondance to clearing bytes and them not being represented as an 'extent' - for example, the implementation of the underlying stream may not permit fine-grained extent storage.
It is always safe to call this method to 'zero-out' a section of a stream, regardless of the underlying stream implementation.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.DiskImageBuilder.Build(System.String)
member.summary: Initiates the construction of the disk image.
member.param: The base name for the disk images.
member.returns: A set of one or more logical files that constitute the disk image. The first file is the 'primary' file that is normally attached to VMs.
member.remarks: The supplied baseName is the start of the file name, with no file extension. The set of file specifications will indicate the actual name corresponding to each logical file that comprises the disk image. For example, given a base name 'foo', the files 'foo.vmdk' and 'foo-flat.vmdk' could be returned.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VirtualDiskLayer
member.summary: Represents the base layer, or a differencing layer of a VirtualDisk.

remarks.para: VirtualDisks are composed of one or more layers - a base layer which represents the entire disk (even if not all bytes are actually stored), and a number of differencing layers that store the disk sectors that are logically different to the base layer.
Disk Layers may not store all sectors. Any sectors that are not stored are logically zero's (for base layers), or holes through to the layer underneath (all other layers).

member.summary: Gets the geometry of the disk as it is anticipated a hypervisor BIOS will represent it.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.DiskClass
member.summary: Gets the type of disk represented by this object.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Capacity
member.summary: Gets the capacity of the disk (in bytes).

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets the size of the disk's logical blocks (in bytes).

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Content
member.summary: Gets the content of the disk as a stream.
member.remarks: Note the returned stream is not guaranteed to be at any particular position. The actual position will depend on the last partition table/file system activity, since all access to the disk contents pass through a single stream instance. Set the stream position before accessing the stream.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Layers
member.summary: Gets the layers that make up the disk.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Signature
member.summary: Gets or sets the Windows disk signature of the disk, which uniquely identifies the disk.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.IsPartitioned
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the disk appears to have a valid partition table.
member.remarks: There is no reliable way to determine whether a disk has a valid partition table. The 'guess' consists of checking for basic indicators and looking for obviously invalid data, such as overlapping partitions.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Partitions
member.summary: Gets the object that interprets the partition structure.
member.remarks: It is theoretically possible for a disk to contain two independant partition structures - a BIOS/GPT one and an Apple one, for example. This method will return in order of preference, a GUID partition table, a BIOS partition table, then in undefined preference one of any other partition tables found. See PartitionTable.GetPartitionTables to gain access to all the discovered partition tables on a disk.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.Parameters
member.summary: Gets the parameters of the disk.
member.remarks: Most of the parameters are also available individually, such as DiskType and Capacity.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.VirtualDisk.DiskTypeInfo
member.summary: Gets information about the type of disk.
member.remarks: This property provides access to meta-data about the disk format, for example whether the BIOS geometry is preserved in the disk file.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Fat.FatBuffer.EndOfChain
member.summary: The End-of-chain marker to WRITE (SetNext). Don't use this value to test for end of chain.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Fat.FatBuffer.BadCluster
member.summary: The Bad-Cluster marker to WRITE (SetNext). Don't use this value to test for bad clusters.
member.remarks: The actual bad-cluster marker bits on disk vary by FAT type.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Fat.FatBuffer.FreeCluster
member.summary: The Free-Cluster marker to WRITE (SetNext). Don't use this value to test for free clusters.
member.remarks: The actual free-cluster marker bits on disk vary by FAT type.

member.summary: Class with generic file system parameters.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.FileSystemParameters.FileNameEncoding
member.summary: Gets or sets the character encoding for file names, or null for default.
member.remarks: Some file systems, such as FAT, don't specify a particular character set for file names. This parameter determines the character set that will be used for such file systems.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.FileSystemParameters.TimeConverter
member.summary: Gets or sets the algorithm to convert file system time to UTC.
member.remarks: Some file system, such as FAT, don't have a defined way to convert from file system time (local time where the file system is authored) to UTC time. This parameter determines the algorithm to use.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to update the ISOLINUX info table at the start of the boot image. Use with ISOLINUX only!
member.remarks: ISOLINUX has an 'information table' at the start of the boot loader that verifies the CD has been loaded correctly by the BIOS. This table needs to be updated to match the actual ISO.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant
member.summary: Enumeration of known file system variants.

remarks.para: ISO9660 has a number of significant limitations, and over time multiple schemes have been devised for extending the standard to support the richer file system semantics typical of most modern operating systems. These variants differ functionally and (in the case of RockRidge) may represent a logically different directory hierarchy to that encoded in the vanilla iso9660 standard.
Use this enum to control which variants to honour / prefer when accessing an ISO image.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.None
member.summary: No known variant.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.Iso9660
member.summary: Vanilla ISO9660.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.Joliet
member.summary: Joliet file system (Windows).

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant.RockRidge
member.summary: Rock Ridge (Unix).

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Iso9660.VfsCDReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VfsCDReader class.
member.param: The stream to read the ISO image from.
Whether to read Joliet extensions.
Hides version numbers (e.g. ";1") from the end of files

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Iso9660.VfsCDReader.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,DiscUtils.Iso9660.Iso9660Variant[],System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VfsCDReader class.
member.param: The stream to read the ISO image from.
Which possible file system variants to use, and with which priority
Hides version numbers (e.g. ";1") from the end of files

remarks.para: The implementation considers each of the file system variants in variantProperties and selects the first which is determined to be present. In this example Joliet, then Rock Ridge, then vanilla Iso9660 will be considered:
remarks.code: VfsCDReader(stream, new Iso9660Variant[] {Joliet, RockRidge, Iso9660}, true);
remarks.para: The Iso9660 variant should normally be specified as the final entry in the list. Placing it earlier in the list will effectively mask later items and not including it may prevent some ISOs from being read.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Net.Dns.MulticastDnsClient
member.summary: Implements the Multicast DNS (mDNS) protocol.
member.remarks: This implementation is a hybrid of a 'proper' mDNS resolver and a classic DNS resolver configured to use the mDNS multicast address. The implementation is aware of some of the unique semantics of mDNS, but because it is loaded in arbitrary processes cannot claim port 5353. It attempts to honour the spirit of mDNS to the extent possible whilst not binding to port 5353.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Exception.NfsStatus
member.summary: Gets the NFS status code that lead to the exception.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status
member.summary: NFS status codes.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.Ok
member.summary: Indicates the call completed successfully.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NotOwner
member.summary: The operation was not allowed because the caller is either not a privileged user (root) or not the owner of the target of the operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NoSuchEntity
member.summary: The file or directory name specified does not exist.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.IOError
member.summary: A hard error (for example, a disk error) occurred while processing the requested operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NoSuchDeviceOrAddress
member.summary: No such device or address.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.AccessDenied
member.summary: The caller does not have the correct permission to perform the requested operation. Contrast this with NotOwner, which restricts itself to owner or privileged user permission failures.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.FileExists
member.summary: The file specified already exists.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.AttemptedCrossDeviceHardLink
member.summary: Attempt to do a cross-device hard link.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NoSuchDevice
member.summary: No such device.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NotDirectory
member.summary: The caller specified a non-directory in a directory operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.IsADirectory
member.summary: The caller specified a directory in a non-directory operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.InvalidArgument
member.summary: Invalid argument or unsupported argument for an operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.FileTooLarge
member.summary: The operation would have caused a file to grow beyond the server's limit.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NoSpaceAvailable
member.summary: The operation would have caused the server's file system to exceed its limit.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.ReadOnlyFileSystem
member.summary: A modifying operation was attempted on a read-only file system.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.TooManyHardLinks
member.summary: Too many hard links.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NameTooLong
member.summary: The filename in an operation was too long.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.DirectoryNotEmpty
member.summary: An attempt was made to remove a directory that was not empty.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.QuotaHardLimitExceeded
member.summary: The user's resource limit on the server has been exceeded.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.StaleFileHandle
member.summary: The file referred to no longer exists or access to it has been revoked.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.TooManyRemoteAccessLevels
member.summary: The file handle given in the arguments referred to a file on a non-local file system on the server.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.BadFileHandle
member.summary: The file handle failed internal consistency checks.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.UpdateSynchronizationError
member.summary: Update synchronization mismatch was detected during a SETATTR operation.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.StaleCookie
member.summary: Directory enumeration cookie is stale.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.NotSupported
member.summary: Operation is not supported.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.TooSmall
member.summary: Buffer or request is too small.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.ServerFault
member.summary: An error occurred on the server which does not map to any of the legal NFS version 3 protocol error values.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.BadType
member.summary: An attempt was made to create an object of a type not supported by the server.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.SlowJukebox
member.summary: The server initiated the request, but was not able to complete it in a timely fashion.
member.remarks: The client should wait and then try the request with a new RPC transaction ID. For example, this error should be returned from a server that supports hierarchical storage and receives a request to process a file that has been migrated. In this case, the server should start the immigration process and respond to client with this error.

member.name: F:DiscUtils.Nfs.Nfs3Status.Unknown
member.summary: An unknown error occured.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListAttribute
member.summary: List of attributes for files that are split over multiple Master File Table entries.

remarks.para: Files with lots of attribute data (for example that have become very fragmented) contain this attribute in their 'base' Master File Table entry. This attribute acts as an index, indicating for each attribute in the file, which Master File Table entry contains the attribute.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.GenericAttribute
member.summary: Base class for all attributes within Master File Table entries.
member.remarks: More specialized base classes are provided for known attribute types.

member.summary: Gets the unique id of the attribute.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the attribute content is stored in the MFT record itself.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.GenericAttribute.Flags
member.summary: Gets the flags indicating how the content of the attribute is stored.

member.summary: Gets the amount of valid data in the attribute's content.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry
member.summary: Represents an entry in an AttributeList attribute.
member.remarks: Each instance of this class points to the actual Master File Table entry that contains the attribute. It is used for files split over multiple Master File Table entries.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry.AttributeType
member.summary: Gets the type of the attribute.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry.AttributeName
member.summary: Gets the name of the attribute (if any).

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry.FirstFileCluster
member.summary: Gets the first cluster represented in this attribute (normally 0).

remarks.para: For very fragmented files, it can be necessary to split a single attribute over multiple Master File Table entries. This is achieved with multiple attributes with the same name and type (one per Master File Table entry), with this field determining the logical order of the attributes.
The number is the first 'virtual' cluster present (i.e. divide the file's content into 'cluster' sized chunks, this is the first of those clusters logically represented in the attribute).

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry.MasterFileTableEntry
member.summary: Gets the Master File Table entry that contains the attribute.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.AttributeListEntry.AttributeIdentifier
member.summary: Gets the identifier of the attribute.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.FileNameAttribute
member.summary: Representation of an NTFS File Name attribute.

remarks.para: Each Master File Table entry (MFT Entry) has one of these attributes for each hard link. Files with a long name and a short name will have at least two of these attributes.

The details in this attribute may be inconsistent with similar information in the StandardInformationAttribute for a file. The StandardInformation is definitive, this attribute holds a 'cache' of the information.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.Internals.FileNameAttribute.ParentDirectory
member.summary: Gets the reference to the parent directory.
member.remarks: This attribute stores the name of a file within a directory, this field provides the link back to the directory.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Ntfs.NtfsFileSystem.PathToClusters(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a file name to the list of clusters occupied by the file's data.
member.param: The path to inspect
member.returns: The clusters as a list of cluster ranges
member.remarks: Note that in some file systems, small files may not have dedicated clusters. Only dedicated clusters will be returned.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Ntfs.NtfsFileSystem.PathToExtents(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a file name to the extents containing its data.
member.param: The path to inspect
member.returns: The file extents, as absolute byte positions in the underlying stream
member.remarks: Use this method with caution - NTFS supports encrypted, sparse and compressed files where bytes are not directly stored in extents. Small files may be entirely stored in the Master File Table, where corruption protection algorithms mean that some bytes do not contain the expected values. This method merely indicates where file data is stored, not what's stored. To access the contents of a file, use OpenFile.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.Ntfs.NtfsOptions.FileLengthFromDirectoryEntries
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether file length information comes from directory entries or file data.

remarks.para: The default (true) is that file length information is supplied by the directory entry for a file. In some circumstances that information may be inaccurate - specifically for files with multiple hard links, the directory entries are only updated for the hard link used to open the file.
Setting this value to false, will always retrieve the latest information from the underlying NTFS attribute information, which reflects the true size of the file.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Partitions.BiosPartitionTable.CreateAligned(DiscUtils.Partitions.WellKnownPartitionType,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new aligned partition that encompasses the entire disk.
member.param: The partition type
Whether the partition is active (bootable)
The alignment (in bytes)
member.remarks: The partition table must be empty before this method is called, otherwise IOException is thrown.

Traditionally partitions were aligned to the physical structure of the underlying disk, however with modern storage greater efficiency is acheived by aligning partitions on large values that are a power of two.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.SnapshotStream

member.name: F:DiscUtils.SnapshotStream._diffExtents
member.summary: Records which byte ranges in diffStream hold changes.

member.name: P:DiscUtils.SparseMemoryBuffer.AllocatedChunks
member.summary: Gets the (sorted) list of allocated chunks, as chunk indexes.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.StreamPump
member.summary: Utility class for pumping the contents of one stream into another.
member.remarks: This class is aware of sparse streams, and will avoid copying data that is not valid in the source stream. This functionality should normally only be used when the destination stream is known not to contain any existing data.

member.summary: Event raised periodically through the pump operation.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.ThreadSafeStream
member.summary: Provides a thread-safe wrapping around a sparse stream.

remarks.para: Streams are inherently not thread-safe (because read/write is not atomic w.r.t. Position). This method enables multiple 'views' of a stream to be created (each with their own Position), and ensures only a single operation is executing on the wrapped stream at any time.
This example shows the pattern of use:
This results in 11 streams that can be used in different streams - tss and ten 'views' created from tss.
Note, the stream length cannot be changed.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.ThreadSafeStream.#ctor(DiscUtils.SparseStream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ThreadSafeStream class.
member.param: The stream to wrap
member.remarks: Do not directly modify toWrap after wrapping it, unless the thread-safe views will no longer be used.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.ThreadSafeStream.#ctor(DiscUtils.SparseStream,DiscUtils.Ownership)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ThreadSafeStream class.
member.param: The stream to wrap
Whether to transfer ownership of toWrap to the new instance
member.remarks: Do not directly modify toWrap after wrapping it, unless the thread-safe views will no longer be used.

The number of bytes of interest
member.returns: An enumeration of stream extents, indicating stored bytes

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VirtualDiskExtent
member.summary: Base class represented a stored extent of a virtual disk.
member.remarks: Some file formats can divide a logical disk layer into multiple extents, stored in different files. This class represents those extents. Normally, all virtual disks have at least one extent.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Vhd.DiskBuilder

member.remarks: Using this method for creating virtual disks avoids consuming large amounts of memory, or going via the local file system when the aim is simply to present a VHD version of an existing disk.

member.summary: Gets the contents of this disk as a stream.

Set the stream position before accessing the stream.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.VolumeManager
member.summary: VolumeManager interprets partitions and other on-disk structures (possibly combining multiple disks).

remarks.para: Although file systems commonly are placed directly within partitions on a disk, in some cases a logical volume manager / logical disk manager may be used, to combine disk regions in multiple ways for data redundancy or other purposes.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeManager.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VolumeManager class.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VolumeManager class.
member.param: The initial disk to add.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeManager.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VolumeManager class.
member.param: Content of the initial disk to add.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeManager.GetPhysicalVolumes(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Gets the physical volumes held on a disk.
member.param: The contents of the disk to inspect

remarks.para: By preference, use the form of this method that takes a disk parameter.
If the disk isn't partitioned, this method returns the entire disk contents as a single volume.

member.name: M:DiscUtils.VolumeManager.GetPhysicalVolumes(DiscUtils.VirtualDisk)
member.summary: Gets the physical volumes held on a disk.
member.param: The disk to inspect
member.remarks: If the disk isn't partitioned, this method returns the entire disk contents as a single volume.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Wim.LzxBitStream
member.summary: Converts a byte stream into a bit stream.

remarks.para: To avoid alignment issues, the bit stream is infinitely long. Once the converted byte stream is consumed, an infinite sequence of zero's is emulated.
It is strongly recommended to use some kind of in memory buffering (such as a BufferedStream) for the wrapped stream. This class makes a large number of small reads.

member.summary: Gets the SHA-1 hash of a file's contents.
member.param: The path to the file
member.remarks: The WIM file format internally stores the SHA-1 hash of files. This method provides access to the stored hash. Callers can use this value to compare against the actual hash of the byte stream to validate the integrity of the file contents.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Compression.HuffmanTree
member.summary: A canonical Huffman tree implementation.
member.remarks: A lookup table is created that will take any bit sequence (max tree depth in length), indicating the output symbol. In WIM files, in practice, no chunk exceeds 32768 bytes in length, so we often end up generating a bigger lookup table than the data it's encoding. This makes for exceptionally fast symbol lookups O(1), but is inefficient overall.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Wim.LzxStream
member.summary: Class to read data compressed using LZX algorithm.
member.remarks: This is not a general purpose LZX decompressor - it makes simplifying assumptions, such as being able to load the entire stream contents into memory..

member.name: M:DiscUtils.Wim.LzxStream.FixupBlockBuffer
member.summary: Fix up CALL instruction optimization.
member.remarks: A slightly odd feature of LZX for optimizing executable compression is that relative CALL instructions (opcode E8) are converted to absolute values before compression. This feature seems to always be turned-on in WIM files, so we have to apply the reverse conversion.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Wim.XpressBitStream
member.summary: Converts a byte stream into a bit stream.
member.remarks: Note the precise read-ahead behaviour of this stream is critical. Some data is read directly from the underlying stream when decoding an Xpress stream - so it's critical the underlying stream position is in the correct location.

member.name: T:DiscUtils.Wim.XpressStream
member.summary: Implements the XPRESS decompression algorithm.
member.remarks: This class is optimized for the case where the entire stream contents fit into memory, it is not suitable for unbounded streams.
